Addition
Ann had 12 apples, and her mom gave her 8 more. How many apples does Ann have now?
There are 15 boys and 13 girls in the class. How many students are there together?
There were 32 books on the shelf. Adam placed 8 more books there. How many books are on the shelf now?
column2: There are 40 books on the shelf now.

column1: Subtraction

column1: Tom had $25. He bought a notebook for $7. How much money does he have left?
There were 24 crayons in the box. The children took 9 crayons. How many crayons were left in the box?
column2: There are 15 crayons left in the box.

column1: Kate had 50 candies. She gave 25 candies to her friends. How many did she have left?
The children gathered 28 mushrooms in the forest. At home, it turned out that 5 of them were wormy and had to be thrown away. How many good mushrooms were left?
column2: The children had 23 good mushrooms left.

column1: Tom had $120. He bought a game for $85. How much money does he have left?
There are 45 chairs in the school. In one room there are 15 chairs, and in the second there are 5 fewer. How many chairs are in the remaining rooms?
There were 30 apples in the shop. 12 apples were sold, and then 8 more were delivered. How many apples are in the shop now?
column2: There are now 26 apples in the shop.
column3: Addition and subtraction of natural numbers

column1: In the park, 5 people were sitting on one bench, and 3 more people were on the second bench than the first. Then 2 people left the second bench. How many people were left on both benches together?
column2: There were 11 people left on both benches together.
column3: Addition and subtraction of natural numbers

column1: Jake had 18 candies. He gave his sister 5 candies, and got 7 more from a friend. How many candies does Jake have now?
column3: Addition and subtraction of natural numbers

column1: There were 40 books in the library. 15 were borrowed, and then 12 new ones were bought. How many books are in the library now?
column2: There are now 37 books in the library.
column3: Addition and subtraction of natural numbers

column1: 18 children were playing on the playground. After a while, 9 more joined, and then 7 went home. How many were left?
column2: There were 20 children left on the playground.

column1: There were 24 students in the class. 8 went out to the sports field, and then 5 new students came from another class. How many students are in the class now?
column2: Now there are 21 students in the class.

column1: There were 20 apples in the basket. 6 were eaten, and then 9 more were added. How many apples are in the basket now?
column2: There are now 23 apples in the basket.

column1: Multiplication
There are 30 desks in the school. There are 2 students sitting at each desk. How many students are in the school?
column2: There are 60 students in the school.

column1: 4 raspberry bushes grew in the garden, and there were 6 fruits on each bush. The children ate 5 raspberries. How many raspberries were left?
column2: There were 19 raspberries left in the garden.

column1: 3 pear trees grew in the orchard, with 8 fruits on each. 10 fruits fell to the ground. How many pears remained on the trees?
column2: There were 14 pears remaining on the trees.

column1: There are 4 rows of carrots in the garden. 5 carrots grow in each row. How many carrots grow in the garden?
Mom bought 3 packs of cookies, with 6 cookies in each pack. How many cookies did Mom buy?
There are 3 plates on the table. There are 4 cookies on each plate. How many cookies are there in total?
Mom bought 3 packs of 5 buns and 2 packs of 4 buns. How many buns did she buy in total?
There were 2 shelves in the closet with 7 books each. 5 more books were added to the bottom shelf. How many books are in the closet?
column2: There are 19 books in the closet in total.

column1: There were 4 shelves in the shop, and there were 8 loaves of bread on each. 10 loaves were sold. How many loaves were left?
column2: There were 22 loaves of bread left in the shop.

column1: Sophie had 5 bags, with 7 candies in each. She ate 8 candies. How many did she have left?
Dad bought 4 packs of water, and there were 6 bottles in each. He gave 5 bottles to the neighbors. How many bottles were left?
column2: Dad had 19 bottles of water left.

column1: 4 rows of flowers grew in the garden, with 7 in each. Then 5 more flowers were planted. How many flowers are in the garden now?
column2: There are 33 flowers in the garden now.

column1: There are 7 rows of books on the shelf, with 12 books in each. How many books are on the shelf?
There are 6 rows of trees in the orchard, with 9 trees in each row. How many trees are in the orchard?
Mom bought 5 baskets of strawberries, with 9 fruits in each. 7 fruits were spoiled. How many good strawberries were left?
In the class, the boys collected $36, and the girls collected twice as much. How much money did the girls collect?
Sophie read 45 pages of a book, and Barbara read 3 times more. How many pages did Barbara read?
Mom baked 3 cakes. She divided each into 8 equal pieces. How many pieces of cake did she have in total?
In the classroom there are 5 rows of 6 desks. How many desks are there together?
There are 5 rows of benches for 2 people in the classroom. How many people fit in the classroom?
The pool is 25 m long. How many meters will Johnny swim if he does 8 lengths of the pool?
Ann has 5 boxes, there are 8 candies in each box. How many candies does she have in total?
7 children are sitting on a bench. Each is holding 2 balloons. How many balloons do they have together?
There were 5 shelves in the shop, with 8 jars of honey on each. 9 jars were sold. How many jars were left in the shop?
column2: There were 31 jars of honey left in the shop.

column1: A cyclist rode for 2 hours at a speed of 18 km/h. What distance did he cover?
A plane flew for 3 hours at a speed of 800 km/h. What distance did it cover?
There is 250 g of rice in one pack. How much rice is in 6 such packs?
Mike has 3 boxes of 250 ml of juice. How much juice does he have in total?
A car burns 7 liters of fuel per 100 km. How much will it burn for 300 km?
4 blouses can be sewn from 5 meters of fabric. How much fabric is needed for 6 blouses?

column1: Division
There were 18 cookies in the box. The children divided them equally among 3 people. How many cookies did each person get?
Mom bought 24 buns. She packed them into bags of 6 buns. How many bags were created?
There were 36 eggs in the basket. They were divided equally into 6 boxes. How many eggs are in each box?
column2: There are 6 eggs in each box.

column1: There are 20 students in the class. They were divided into 4 equal teams. How many people are in each team?
column2: There are 5 people in each team.

column1: There were 32 apples in the orchard. 8 were sold, and the rest were divided equally into 4 crates. How many apples went into one crate?
Mom baked 20 muffins. The children ate 8, and she packed the rest equally into 4 boxes. How many muffins were in each box?
column2: There were 3 muffins in each box.

column1: There were 25 flowers in the garden. 5 withered, and the remaining ones were divided equally into 4 flowerbeds. How many flowers were in each flowerbed?
column2: There were 5 flowers in each flowerbed.

column1: Ann had 15 candies. She gave 3 friends the same amount of candies and had none left. How many candies did each friend get?
There were 12 bananas on the table. The children took 3 bananas each. How many children took bananas?
28 children went on a trip. The bus holds 7 people. How many trips must it make to transport all the children?
column2: The bus must make 4 trips to transport all the children.

column1: There were 36 balls on the field. 12 were taken to the storage, and the rest were divided equally among 4 teams. How many balls did each team have?
There were 28 students in the class. 10 went to a competition, and the remaining ones were divided equally into 3 groups. How many people were in each group?
column2: There were 6 people in each group.

column1: 40 children went on a trip. 12 of them went by bus, and the rest fit equally into 4 vans. How many children were in each van?
column2: There were 7 children in each van.

column1: Sophie gathered 48 nuts. On the way she lost 8, and distributed the rest equally into 4 jars. How many nuts were in each jar?
column2: There were 10 nuts in each jar.

column1: 12 pigeons were sitting on a bench. 4 of them flew away, and the rest were divided equally into 2 groups. How many pigeons were in each group?
column2: There were 4 pigeons in each group.

column1: There are 60 seats in the cinema. There are 10 seats in the first row, and in the remaining rows there are 5 people sitting equally in each row. How many rows did these people occupy?
Grandpa had 30 eggs. He placed them equally into 6 baskets, and then added 2 eggs to each basket. How many eggs does each basket have now?
There were 24 crayons in the class. They were divided equally among 4 students, and then one student gave 2 crayons to a friend. How many crayons does this friend have now?
There were 42 books in the school. They were placed equally on 7 shelves, and then 3 books were taken from one shelf. How many were left on that shelf?
column2: 3 books were left on that shelf.

column1: There were 19 lollipops in the pack. They were placed equally on 3 plates. How many lollipops were on each plate and how many were left?
column2: There were 6 lollipops on each plate, and 1 lollipop was left.

column1: Tom bought 27 balloons. He distributed them equally to 5 friends, and kept the rest for himself. How many balloons did each friend get and how many were left for Tom?
column2: Each friend got 5 balloons, and Tom had 2 balloons left.

column3: "Cross out" all common zeros (in this case two 0s) and you are left with only 210 Ã· 7 to calculate
"Cross out" all common zeros (in this case one 0) and you are left with only 1800 Ã· 3 to calculate
"Cross out" all common zeros (in this case four 0s) and you are left with only 50 Ã· 1 to calculate
